Message
Highlights

2 mutual groups

You and Theopista are both in Sustainable Agriculture & Rural Development and Climate Change / ESG Professionals Group

About

I am Abalo Theopista, a final year forestry student at Makerere University. I served  as the regional representative of Southern Africa with the International Forestry Students Association, and currently an FAO Young Forest Champion 2025.

I am passionate about  research  in  areas of sustainable forest resource management and utilization. I am always eager to contribute to a more sustainable world for a better mother nature and the life it houses. 

I'm a skilled communicator and collaborative team leader, with a strong ability to learn and adapt quickly. I'm passionate about continuous growth and seeking opportunities to challenge myself, particularly in initiatives and organizations that prioritize sustainable natural resource management and environmental protection. I believe in working towards a future where our natural resources are preserved and utilized responsibly, without compromising the environment's integrity.

Gad Okodi • 2nd

Forester ||Young Forest Champion ||

6d • Edited • 

I’m happy to share that I’m starting a new position as GLF/YiL Focal Point person at International Forestry Students'​ Association (IFSA).

In this role, I’ll be working closely with the External Councilor and Head of Partner Commission Theopista Abalo to strengthen IFSA’s collaboration with the Global Landscapes Forum (GLF) and Youth in Landscape Initiative (YIL). 

I will empower young forestry voices, fostering partnerships, and amplifying youth-led actions for sustainable landscapes.

I look forward to contributing to a more connected and impactful global forestry community who are acting locally but impacting globally🌳

Davis Ssemanda • 2nd

Forester. Ecologist. Research. Environmental Consultant.

1mo • 

Honoured to be featured by the Food and Agriculture Organization FAO for my work on forest health in Uganda. 
👉https://lnkd.in/dXmBAaPq 👈

This recognition is a reminder of the importance of innovation, collaboration, and empowering early-career professionals in addressing global environmental challenges.

The feature followed my participation in the Youth Action in Forest Health Competition, where I shared research on paper mulberry invasion in Mabira forest, subsequently winning a scholarship at BFU. 

Thank you to everyone who continues to support and inspire this journey. Onwards!

Theopista Abalo reposted this

EcoFreak

130 followers

2mo • 

🎍Did you know some bamboos run🏃‍♀️? 
Lets catch them today🫷

The famous Phyllostachys species are  the most notorious running bamboo species. Their rhizomes  spread aggressively over the entire area in which one single shoot was planted with the underground rhizomes allowing for new shoots and culms to emerge. Depending on the situation,it could be a disadvantage due to high costs of maintenance or perhaps an advantage interms of high yields associated with it.

🌳At EcoFreak, we are raising the alternative choice. The Oxytenanthera abyssinica famously know as the African bamboo and the ever green bamboo.🍃
It is mostly a clumping bamboo that grows in dense cluster of culms in a contained area making it non invasive and easy to manage. It's rhizomes spread but not as much as the Phyllostachys.

It's is one of the most versitile bamboo in terms of application and growing conditions. It grows in the  East and Central Africa.🌍
 
Unlike most bamboo species which are hollow and light weight, the African Bamboo has solid or semi solid culms that gives it a superior tensile strength making it one of the top choices for construction🏗 and furniture🚪.With this, It's a natural alternative to timber, reducing pressure on forests🌳🌳.

Because of its drought resistance, its able to grow in dry areas and with an extensive root system  its suitable for erosion control. Its can therefore be grown along river banks . All these make it one of the Climate solutions we need🍁

🌳As we protect out forests we have to think of other feasible alternatives to ensure sustainability in our efforts👣

The interesting things about value addition in Bamboo  as we saw at Amabanda Uganda Limited is the true definition of a zero waste and  circular economy that we so much need right now.

And for the african bamboo every part of the plant has a purpose. The leaves serve as valuable animal fodder, the young shoots are a source of food, and the stems can be processed into biofuel and more.

📌Which bamboo fact did you just find out? Share with your thoughts with us in the comments.

Special Thanks to Dr Charles Koojo Amooti from #KontikibambooWorks for his presentation on Common Bamboo species in Uganda during the Amabanda Uganda Limited Bamboo processing Masterclass.

#sustainability #bioeconomy #africanbamboo #innovation #sustainablesolutions
#climateaction

Theopista Abalo reposted this

EcoFreak

130 followers

2mo • 

🎋The more the sustainable solutions the better for our forests!!🎋

We recently attended a highly informative Masterclass on the Commercial Processing of bamboo, hosted by Bamboo Uganda and its partners, like Bijimu Bamboo Farming Services Amabanda Uganda Limited and EKiBBO Farming Services Ltd.

 It was inspiring to see so many architects👲 in attendance, a clear sign that sustainable solutions are becoming mainstream and a significant part of our daily choices ✅️ 

🎍Bamboo is more than just a material it's one of the carbon storing Gurus. By transforming it into beautiful crafts and durable buildings, we're locking away carbon and building a more sustainable future.

 🎍The session provided a deep dive into the entire process, from treating the raw material to converting it into a wide range of finished products. Every piece of beautiful craft or strong building contributes to this effort.

🎍However, despite all these innovations, a critical question remains, why is the number of bamboo farmers still so low? 

Institutions like Amabanda Uganda Limited are at the forefront of this solution. They empower 🧑‍🧑‍🧒‍🧒 communities by teaching them to grow bamboo,they purchase their harvests, and also train them to create various products. 

🍃For a forest community, this not only sustains their livelihoods but also provides a viable alternative to forest dependency.

🎋Considering that it takes up to six years for bamboo to reach maturity, it feels like we are six years behind in our efforts to protect more forests.

In the coming days, we will be sharing more of our takeaways from this incredible session, including a look at the different types of bamboo species right here in Uganda and beyond, their treatment methods, and their immense benefits to the environment.🌏

Stay tuned to learn more!


#sustainability
#bamboorevolution
#sustainablealternatives

Theopista Abalo reposted this

Eva Ntara • 2nd

Artsy Environmentalist

3mo • 

From 14–16 July, I facilitated the #AIM4Forests Young #ForestChampions workshop in Kampala, Uganda – an inspiring gathering of 10 passionate young leaders from across the country.

Organized by FAO Uganda, the Ministry of Water and Environment, the National Forestry Authority, and Youth Go Green, the workshop focused on equipping Uganda’s next generation of forest leaders to support the country’s goal of reaching 24% forest cover by 2040.

We planted 200 indigenous seedlings at Mpanga Forest Reserve and used FAO’s Open Foris Ground to geolocate each tree gaining hands-on experience in digital forest monitoring.

Read more here: https://lnkd.in/dPhvvJb4

What stood out to me most? I left this workshop feeling incredibly hopeful. Young people are not just passionate, they’re prepared. With the right tools, skills, and networks, they’re ready to lead forest restoration efforts from the ground up.

#ForestChampions #AIM4Forests #YouthInForestry #ClimateAction #ForestMonitoring #UgandaForests #GenerationRestoration #OpenForis #GlobalYouthAction #Forestry

Julian Fox,Till Neeff, Nadir Carolina Pallqui Camacho, Vanessa Vertiz, Billy Rwothungeyo, Pilar Valbuena Perez, Enock Kaluuba, Edwin Muhumuza, Theopista Abalo, LANDO IVAN, Gad Okodi, Samuel Tahinduka, LOVIC BWAMBALE, Pius Turinawe, Ekel Fiona, Patricia Arinaitwe, Margret Nabagereka, Bako Patience, Elizabeth Kabakoyo, Racheal Katushabe, Katalikawe William, Bob Kazungu

Theopista Abalo reposted this

Amabanda Uganda Limited

1,615 followers

3mo • 

What an incredible day we had at the Bamboo Uganda Masterclass last Saturday the 26th of July 2025! 🌱✨ 

We were thrilled to host a diverse group of enthusiasts, entrepreneurs, and industry experts at Amabanda Uganda Limited (the bamboo processing facility) in Kiyoola, Mukono. This event was not just about learning; it was about building a community passionate about the potential of bamboo in Uganda.

Here are some highlights from the day:

1. Factory Tour: 
Our General Manager, Collin Muhumuza, led an insightful tour of our state-of-the-art bamboo processing facility. Attendees were able to see firsthand how we transform bamboo into valuable products, showcasing the innovation and potential within this industry.

2. Best Bamboo Species for Processing:
Dr Koojo Charles Amooti, GM of Kontiki Bamboo Works Ltd, shared his expertise on the best bamboo species for commercial processing. His insights were invaluable for those looking to optimize their bamboo production.

3. The Dos & Don’ts of Bamboo Treatment: Herwig Van Geenhoven, a co-founder of Amabanda Uganda Limited, provided practical tips on bamboo treatment. His session was filled with essential knowledge that will help our participants avoid common pitfalls.

4. Common Business Mistakes:
Robert Ssemakula, Bcom, LLM., GM of Bamboo Uganda, discussed critical business mistakes to avoid to ensure profitability in the bamboo sector. His experience and advice resonated with many aspiring entrepreneurs.

5. Alternative Income Streams for Bamboo Farmers: Sophie Arcedeckne-Butler, Managing Director of EKiBBO Farming Services Ltd, enlightened us on alternative income streams for bamboo farmers. Her innovative ideas opened new avenues for income generation, emphasizing the versatility of bamboo.

6. Certificate of Training: 
We concluded the day by awarding Certificates of Training in Commercial Processing of Bamboo: The Dos & Don’ts of Bamboo Treatment Series 1. It was a proud moment to recognize the commitment of participants to advancing their knowledge and skills in this field.

We are grateful to everyone who joined us and contributed to the success of this event. Your enthusiasm and commitment to the bamboo industry inspire us to continue our mission of promoting sustainable bamboo value addition in Uganda.

Swipe through the photos to relive the moments from this enriching experience! 📸

Together, let’s harness the power of bamboo to create a sustainable future and unlock new opportunities for our communities.

Bamboo Uganda + Bijimu Bamboo Farming Services + EKiBBO Farming Services Ltd + Amabanda Uganda Limited + Studio Akeka

#BambooUganda #Sustainability #ValueAddition #Innovation #CommunityBuilding #AmabandaUganda

Theopista Abalo • 1st

FAO Young Forest Champion| Passionate about Sustainable Forest Resource Utilization

3mo • 

A voice 4forests!!
I recently participated in a 3days workshop and training for the FAO #YoungForestChampions under the #AIM4Forests program.  

The event was launched by Mr. Stuart Maniraguha, the Executive Director of the #NationalForestryAuthority(NFA), who shared extensive insights about the history of the forestry department, tracing its roots from the 1940s to the present day. In the same room, we were honoured to have knowledgeable foresters like Ndyabandiho saul and Derrick Rukundo from the #MinistryofWaterandEnvironment,  who inspired budding foresters like me with their stories of how they progressed from their early studies to their current positions.

We learnt about the FAO's forest monitoring tools and their practical applications in the field. One tool, called #Ground, is user-friendly and can operate offline with a pre-created data collection survey. On the last day, while at the #MpangaCFR, we practically used it to map the trees we planted. This will help us trace and monitor their growth.
 💃I highly recommend trying #Ground for tree growers and restoration initiatives.

The #NFAteam at #MpangaCFR provided us with a wealth of information about the forest, describing it as one of the ecosystems that hosts a diverse range of butterflies and bird species. As such, it's a great destination for recreational activities like bird watching and research. However, despite all these positive aspects, #MpangaCR, like many others in Uganda, is one of the most threatened areas. Its location within the Mpigi District Town Council leads to uncontrolled access, particularly from illegal loggers.

This forest was significantly impacted about ten years ago by a windstorm that uprooted trees over 100 years old, affecting half of the 400 hectares of the reserve. The reasons for this event remain unknown; thus, further research is needed. Following this loss and ongoing threats, the forest canopy is heavily gapped, and it will take over 30 years or more for it to regain its usual state. 🤷‍♀️How best can we assist in its recovery?
👉 I encourage #NGOs and other organisations looking to make an impact through tree planting to consider the #MpangaCFR as a key site for their initiatives.

🧏‍♀️Effective communication is one of the essential aspects of sustainable forest management. Access to information enables us to make informed decisions and agree on the best solutions with various stakeholders and partners.
🦻 I plan to share forest stories with the community, translating scientific and technical jargon into simple, easy to understand language. This influence starts from the inside(hearts) to the outside (hands).

Thank you, Eva Ntara, Rocío Dánica Cóndor-Golec, Julian Fox, the FAO Country team, #YouthGoGreenteam, Muhumuza Edwin, #NFA and #MOWE for providing this platform. This is a launchpad for many of us.

Thank you to all my fellow #youngforestchampions, this experience couldn't have been better without you all.
Pius Turinawe Ekel Fiona

Theopista Abalo reposted this

Samuel Tahinduka • 2nd

An Autodidact | Research Assistant @ Catholic Relief Services | Geographical Sciences  | Young Forest Champion Uganda 2025  | Global Forests Spokesperson

3mo • Edited • 

From 14th to 16th July 2025, I had the incredible opportunity to take part in the #AIM4Forests Young Forest Champions Workshop in Uganda, an initiative by FAO , in collaboration with the National Forestry Authority Uganda, Ministry of Water and Environment, Youth Go Green and World Food Forum Uganda Chapter.

This workshop brought together passionate young champions from across Uganda carrying stories, dreams, and commitment to sustainable forest management and climate action. Through intense capacity-building sessions, we explored themes such as:

🔹 Participatory forest monitoring and conservation 
🔹 Indigenous knowledge and biodiversity
🔹 Climate resilience through forest landscape restoration
🔹 Opportunities for youth in sustainable forest enterprises etc

We later had a field visit to Mpanga Forest Central Reserve, a biodiversity-rich ecosystem in Mpigi District. During this visit, we translated our learning into action by planting indigenous tree species critical for restoration and local livelihoods. We also practically used FAO's Open Foris Ground mobile application to collect data on the planted species for smooth monitoring purposes.

I personally planted three different tree species with significant ecological and cultural value:
1.Warburgia ugandensis; known for its medicinal properties
2.Prunus africana; valued for both its medicinal bark and conservation status
3.Markhamia lutea; an important species for both shade and soil protection
This symbolises hope, commitment, and youth-driven action toward reversing forest loss and land degradation.

I am deeply grateful to FAO and all facilitators and fellow participants who made this experience so meaningful. This workshop did not only deepen my technical knowledge, but also reaffirmed my vision for youth-led forest monitoring and environmental stewardship.
Eva Ntara Gad Okodi Theopista Abalo Bwambale Lovic Bako Patience LANDO IVAN Rocío Dánica Cóndor-Golec Julian Fox
#AIM4Forests
#YoungForestChampions

Theopista Abalo reposted this

Gad Okodi • 2nd

Forester ||Young Forest Champion ||

3mo • Edited • 

#FieldDay in #MpangaCentralForest Reserve as part of the Young Forest Champions workshop in Kampala!

Today, we had a field visit to Mpanga Forest, a 400-hectare gazetted central forest reserve having 29 reserves since 1932, supports an impressive and amazing biodiversity for such a small forest. It has 500 species of trees and shrubs including Celtis Spp, 300 species of birds, 97 butterflies, and 112 moths but facing significant challenges. A recent windthrow disaster of 2015 affected 200 hectares of the forest, prompting restoration efforts by the Grow partner. Recent research has revealed that the forest's soil is sandy, which could be the cause of the disturbance, however, research is needed to understand the underlying causes of these natural disasters and  ensure the forest's future sustainability. The forest's unique characteristics, with bigger trees and limited undergrowth, raise concerns about its resilience.

Despite being surrounded by a human-dominated landscape and facing pressure from firewood collection and illegal tree cutting by the drum makers, Mpanga Forest remains a vital haven for biodiversity. It's renowned for its exceptional butterfly and birding opportunities and when visited at night, you can have a chance of spotting the #bushbabies . 

In the field,  we also had a chance of participation in the restoration of the forest through strip planting and tree species planted include: Cordia milleni(Drum tree), Cynometra alexandria(Iron wood),  khaya anthotheca(Mahogany), Maesopsis eminii(Umbrella tree), Prunus africana(African cherry), Werbugia ugandensis(Mukuzanume,Covidex), among others. 

Above all,  all these tree seedlings  planted were mapped using the skills we obtained from the training by Eva Ntara on #OpenForisGround to map trees planted by automatically taking coordinates,  tree species name,  time,  and any other relevant information after making a polygon in the app for a given restoration site for effective restoration reporting and monitoring. 

Besides I'm thrilled to be awarded a certificate of completion of the 3 day workshop for Young Forest Champions in Kampala Uganda and I'm grateful to the organizers like Eva Ntara Julian Fox Nadir Carolina Pallqui Camacho Rocío Dánica Cóndor-Golec and partners like national forestry authority nfa FAO World Food Forum Ndyabandiho saul Derrick Rukundo @Youth Go Green Uganda @Ministry of water and environment Uganda. 

With restoration underway, it's crucial to balance conservation efforts with community needs and address the underlying causes of threats to ensure the long-term survival of this precious ecosystem.

To my fellow champions Theopista Abalo Bwambale Lovic Samuel Tahinduka Ekel Fiona Patricia Arinaitwe Margret Nabagereka Bako Patience LANDO IVAN Pius Turinawe I'm grateful to have you all. 

"When we rise for forests, forests rise for us all" Gad 2025😃

#AIM4Forests
#YoungForestChampions
